sentences: Mike Kowalski (born July 28, 1944) is a drummer, percussionist and musicologist.
He is best known as a longtime touring and session drummer for the rock band the Beach Boys.
Early career ==
Mike Kowalski was born in Hollywood, Los Angeles, California.
He started singing and playing piano at the age of three.
His first professional engagement was playing boogie-woogie piano with Mel Torme on drums for a television pilot at the age of five, filmed on location at Bimbo's 365 Club in San Francisco.
At age ten, he was given a set of Slingerland Radio-King drums by actor Jack Webb of Dragnet, a noted jazz aficionado.
At the age of fifteen, he was playing drums professionally with various local rock and rhythm and blues bands.
He performed both on stage and on screen as his family was affiliated with the film and television industries.
By age nineteen he was playing drums with Los Angeles-based singers Pat and Lolly Vegas, whom later formed the pop/rock group Redbone.
Also during this time, Kowalski performed and recorded with Sonny & Cher, Little Anthony & the Imperials and Etta James.
Kowalski, along with the Vegas Brothers and several players from The Wrecking Crew, recorded "Laugh At Me", Sonny Bono's only hit song as a solo artist.
Produced by Bono and Snuff Garrett, the song reached the Top 10 in the US, UK, and Canada in August 1965.
At age 21, Kowalski was the drummer on the record.
On January 3, 1968, Kowalski flew to London to join Ed Carter's blues rock band, The New Nadir, with Gary Thain on bass.
Over the next several months, The New Nadir performed regularly on the city's club circuit.
The trio shared the bill at the Marquee Club with Jethro Tull, Ten Years After, The Nice, the Aynsley Dunbar Retaliation, and the Jeff Beck Group, to name a few.
A highlight for Kowalski was at the Speakeasy, when Carter's friend Jimi Hendrix sat in with the band.
In March, producer Joe Boyd signed The New Nadir to his production company, Witchseason Productions.
The New Nadir recorded three songs for Boyd, written by Carter and Peter Dawkins.
In May, the group disbanded.
Kowalski and Carter returned to Los Angeles, while Thain remained in London, eventually gaining recognition with Keef Hartley and Uriah Heep.
In the winter of 1969, Kowalski and Carter returned to London to fulfill their contract to Witchseason Productions.
The album they recorded reflects and combines their passion for Latin jazz, rock and country music.
During this period, Kowalski drummed on albums by John Martyn, Beverley Martyn, Dudu Pukwana, Mike Heron and Nick Drake; all of the aforementioned were signed to Witchseason Productions.
In 1968, Kowalski met Dawn Aston from Kent, England.
They were married in California in 1969.

sentences: In mid-June 1968, the Beach Boys were in the process of adding additional rhythm and horn sections for their upcoming summer tour.

sentences: Auditions were held in the afternoon in Hollywood at the Moulin Rouge Supper Club on Sunset Boulevard.

sentences: Bruce Johnston suggested Ed Carter for bass and guitar, Daryl Dragon for keyboards, and Kowalski for percussion and drums.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: The three auditioned and were hired.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: In November, Kowalski was called into the studio to play drums on Dennis Wilson's "All I Want to Do".
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: Primarily written and produced by Wilson (with lyrics from poet and band associate Stephen Kalinich), the song was released on 20/20 (1969).
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: After briefly touring with the group as an auxiliary percussionist in 1968, Kowalski played his first show on drums at the Big Sur Folk Festival in Monterey, California on October 3, 1970, filling in for Wilson, who was then filming Monte Hellman's Two-Lane Blacktop (1971).
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: In 1971, Kowalski was again on drums as the Beach Boys performed a mid-bill slot at the invitation-only closing night of New York City's Fillmore East on June 27 and filmed the NBC special Good Vibrations From Central Park on July 2.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: Wilson was unable to play drums at both concerts because of a recent hand injury, although he continued to sing and play keyboards.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: After the Central Park show, the Beach Boys flew back to Los Angeles.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: The next day, Kowalski was on a plane to Tokyo, playing drums with Johnny Otis on a tour of the Far East.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: He would continue to perform in Otis' ensemble from 1971 to 1974, juggling dates between both bands until 1973.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: In the summer of 1971, fellow multi-instrumentalist Ricky Fataar began touring with the Beach Boys, ultimately becoming a full member of the band in March 1972.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: He served as the band's principal drummer until the autumn of 1974, by which time Wilson had resumed drumming.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: The presence of Fataar in the expanding touring band enabled Kowalski to play a variety of instruments, including several forms of percussion, the Moog synthesizer and even occasional lead guitar (as heard on The Beach Boys in Concert [1973]).
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: Several years later, Kowalski rejoined the Beach Boys touring band from 1977 to 1978, sharing drumming responsibilities with Wilson and singer/multi-instrumentalist Bobby Figueroa (who joined the touring band in 1974).
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: He also performed intermittently in Celebration, a Mike Love-led side project that featured Carter and other prominent members of the touring band.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: During this period, he appeared on The Beach Boys M.I.U. Album, Celebration's Almost Summer and Beach Boys touring member Charles Lloyd's Weavings.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: In October 1981, Wilson and Figueroa were unable to tour.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: Kowalski, after a three-year absence from the band, returned to play drums.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: By the end of the year, Kowalski and Wilson, who was back on drums, performed during the band's controversial holiday engagement in apartheid-era Sun City, South Africa.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: 1982 had Kowalski playing drums for Mike Love's Endless Summer Beach Band (featuring Dean Torrence), and drums and percussion with The Beach Boys.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: By March 1983, there were two sets of drums on stage as Wilson continued to struggle with substance abuse; both Kowalski and Wilson played shows together until Wilson's death on December 28, 1983.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: For the next 23 years, Kowalski would tour exclusively with The Beach Boys, playing drums until he parted ways with them in September 2007.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: In 1984, Kowalski collaborated with Joel Peskin to create The Backsters.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: They were signed to A & M Records with Herb Alpert as executive producer.
section: == The Beach Boys and The Backsters ==

sentences: Their album, entitled Get on Your Back, featured many seasoned jazz and blues players.

sentences: Other bands and performers ==
Kowalski has played with numerous bands and performers; both as a member of the group and as a session musician.
Acts Kowalski has played with include:
